Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Medium: Collaborative Research: Promoting Secondary Spectrum Markets via Profitability-Driven Methods and Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless telecommunications are undergoing substantial policy reforms in pursuit of better spectral efficiency. A key element in these reforms entails granting full property rights to spectrum license holders, thereby paving the way to secondary spectrum markets. Spectrum markets hold a remarkable potential to increase spectrum utilization by making it available to a larger fraction of public at lower cost. Yet, although a favorable regulatory framework has been in effect in the last few years, liquidity of spectrum markets is inhibited due to uncertainties perceived by spectrum license holders. These uncertainties stem from complex relationships between effects of electromagnetic interference and economic considerations. This research involves a constructive study of viability of spectrum markets by establishing methods and algorithms that render such markets profitable for their participants.

The investigators focus on analytical study of profitability of spectrum markets, and its empirical verification. Main thrusts of the research program are: (i) fundamental elements of pricing and interference externalities for efficient and economically viable use of spectrum; (ii) algorithms for spot market use and real-time measurement-based pricing policies; (iii) empirical techniques for testing demand model specification, and formative models of demand-price relationships via experimental studies. This research is interdisciplinary and it is based on identifying incarnations of both novel and classical notions in economics in the specific context of wireless communications and spectrum markets.

The research impacts legal and economic policies for the future wireless industry and provides a tool for assessing potentials of the secondary spectrum market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addresses the changes we are observing over recent years in the wireless telecommunication market. In particular,  policy reforms that grant full property rights to spectrum license holders. This has created what is commonly referred to as a secondary spectrum market. Spectrum markets hold a remarkable potential to increase spectrum utilization by making it available to a larger fraction of public at lower cost. The purpose of this project was to provide a constructive study of viability of spectrum markets by establishing methods and algorithms that render such markets profitable for their participants.

The project has contributed on the intellectual merit front by developing analytical frameworks to study profitability, which determines spectrum market viability. It also created tools to verify  empirically the main analytical findings via simulation engines and numerical methods.   Our results fill an important niche which was absent from academic studies so far, namely, the focus on profitability in driving the economics of such markets, as opposed to profit maximization which is the typical formulation one sees in the economics literature.  Our work provides formal models that make significant contributions in engineering and economics. Notable milestones in the project include: the development of online dynamic pricing algorithms that account for spatio-temporal uncertainties (e.g.,  interference externalities, and parameter changes over time), which support viable use of spectrum;  (ii) algorithms for spot market use and real-time measurement-based pricing policies which have been extensively tested in our simulation engine; and  (iii) statistical techniques for testing demand model specification that inform further development and refinement of demand curves for spectrum markets. Research contributions have appeared in over 15  peer-reviewed publications and have been presented at conferences, academic institutions and industry forums.    

The project has had a broader impact that extends beyond its formal academic output. By working on the interface of economics, engineering, machine learning and operations research, the work has contributed to synergies between these academic disciplines. It has also helped attract students both to designated courses and seminars, as well as train and produce future thought leaders that have taken on significant starting positions in academia and industry. Knowledge has been disseminated in the traditional avenues but has also benefitted from close collaboration with industry partners, and industry-academic forums specific to the PIs home institutions (the center for tele information at Columbia, for example).  Various papers arising from the project are given regularly as seminar readings at graduate level classes in several top academic institutions. Algorithms developed in the project have been made available to the broad scientific community and have been used in various follow up studies at other institutions, and industry standards have been affected by insights generated by the project, which have the potential to alter state-of-the-art methodologies in several contexts.
